Those WHO have had an opportunity Of
attending .he course of Lectures, now about
10 close, in this Borough, and delivered by
Mr. Joha finch, on the science OF Geology,
&c. have been instructed and Interested
much beyond thcjr previous anticipations'--
In SO concise and SO lucid manner, has be
gone on to unfold to his class, the secrets and
the beauties Of the science; and TO display
to them, feature BY feature, the Internal
structure Of the o,b on which we live, that
he has, in few short weeks, impressed up
on their minds such a general knowledge oi
the subject, as would require months to OBJ
tain, by the common course of study. his
illustrations OF the Classification of fossils;
and his exhibition OF the various specimena,
which he tool, pains to famiiarizc to the
eyes CT his pupils, has likewise given to them
practical idea of Miner alogy, that they
could by no other means acquired Il IS to
be regretted, however, that comparative
few only of our inhabitants, have had the
advantage of these lectures, owing to the fact
that sufficient early publicity was not given
of their commencement, by the proposer.-
Many, thus, were ignorant OF the circum-
stance, who would have otherwise ayaied
themselves Of so favorable an opportunity
to become acquainted, with the too little
known geological arcana of our Globe.


We could wish, on this account, that Mr..
Finch would repeat his course of Lectures
in this Borough. Another Glass; it is pre-
sumed, would be readily formed; and the
youth of both sexes in our town. (the vicini-
tv of which is fertile in Mineral productiens)
would, by storing their minds with knowl-
edge of this interesting science, be capable
Of receiving increased pleasure from their
rides and their rambles through the country

The Canandian Spectator mentions. that
one-seventh part of the soil of Upper Cana
tla belongs to the Episcopalian clergy, who
however at present minister to only one
twentieth part of the population. This fea-
ture in the system of course keeps large
portion of the country uncultivated aud
large part of the people dissatisfied.


Fahe Nose.--A French surgeon has late
ly restored to an individual his nose, which
had been frost bitten during the campaign
in Russia. The usual mode was adopted of
turning down a portion of the skin of the
forehead for the purpose. The result is ve-
~ satisfactory. The detormity is scarcely
observable, and the scar in the forehead,
conccaled also in some degree by the hair,
has almost entir ly disappeared. What is
very extraordinary, is, that the person Oh
whom this operation has been performed,
II tcrs 90 lis forehead all the SENSATIONS of
his false nose; The nerves of which arc in fact
furnished by .hc nervous branches intended
for tie forehead.

The Canandian Spectator mentions. that
one-seventh part of the soil Of Upper Cana
ta belongs to the Episcopalian clergy, who
however at present minister to only one
twentieth part of the population. This fea-
ture in the system of course keeps large
portion of the country uncultivated aud a
large part of the people dissatisfied.

full articles.headline: A Valuable Farm for Sale.
full articles.article:
nz,Lh rs offered 70 private saie,a FuhtG-
fsrsI...lag3 "a Jhe Farn, situated in Pencader
tsssu8as hundred, Newcastle County, Del a.
ssssssZ2-- -zs bout mile south ofEcwark; adioin-
ing lands Of r H. llotzbeckcr, the heirs OF Will
liam Lindsey, :. c., Zachariah Jones, and others,
containing LOG acres, "inore or less" Ibis Farm
Is on black oak and hickory soil. in high state
Of cultivation, and equaled by few in the neigh.
bourhool;--it is well adapted to all kinds Of
dresses and G,ain;-has on il a young thriving
orchard of about one hundred trees Of choice
fruits an excellent bottom meadow, through
which runs a never falling stream; and seven til
lages OF fields, all un,!er good fence, The i'm
provcmens are Il two story log dwelling house,
we'll weathcr-boarded outside and lathed and
plastcred inside. having three rooms down and
four up stairs, with first rate cellar under the
whole.-Also, kitchen adjoining, with pump
Of excellent water at the door; stone milk
house and a smoke house; frame barn, nearly
new. with excellent s,abling underneath, suiH
cent to hold ten or twelve head Of horses, be-
sides mich COWS, calves, &C. Further descrip.
ton is deemed unnecessary, as it is expected
that any wishing to purchase will view the prem
iscs which the subscriber, living thereon, can
show, and make known the conditions Of sale.


JOHN PITNER.

full articles.headline: pARKER'S pANACEA.
full articles.article:
The Proprietor of Parkcr's Panacea has
the satisfaction of laying before the public,
the following recommrndatory notice of his
Medicine from Dir. Edwin A. Atlce, high
ly respectable practitioner in Philadelphia.


"fiay ing been requested to state, what ex-
ncyicnce have had Of the efficacy of Park
cr's PanQcea, ! am enabled to say, that
three patients, who have used of the bottles
preeputcd for trial, have evidently derived
great benefit. The first is a respectable fe-
male, who laboured under extreme Scrofu-
lous debility, in which the stomach partici-
pated iargcly--its digestive functions being
much tisordered. After taking one bottle,
her health was improved-her appetite, di
gcston, and complexion meliorated; and in
the use of tho second bottle, her GONZALES
cence is speedy.


The second, is the son OF board nicr-
chant, who suffers with the hip-disease, a
scrofu!ous affection or carries of the neck OF
the thigh bouc. Previously to the use of
parker's Panacca, he had habitually suffer
cd great pain in the affected part, and his
general health was much impaired. He has
taken nearly two bottles. and his parents say
he has been more free Of pain than before,
while his general health is fast improving.


The third is Lady, whose disease is
supposed to be Rheumatic--and who has
lone suffered with an extensive ulcer of the
leg. resisting the remedies prescribed by
two regular and eminent physicians, who
apprehcnded the loss of the limb by gan
CREME. By request, l called to see her to-
day; viewed the ulcer, which is now not
more than fourth, in diameter and depth,
of what it was originally-is much less swol-
len, very slightly painful-and she says she
has received mare benefit from the two bot
ties of Parker's Panacea. than from any
medicine that had been before administer
ed"


II the above recommendatory notice is cal
culated to benefit the proprietor. i, is at MS
service, K. A. ATLEE.
l4I;u SfL mo 20 1907

In Justice to myself, have been induced 20
reply to a false ,rd unjustiliable attack made
upon me and others by Swain, the ycnder OF 4
certain Panacea in this city. do this also, in or
der to remove from the public mind, the false
impressions which may arise out of his pompous
and incorrect statement III the public prints -
Mr.. Swain wishes 10 establish the belief that he
is the sole patentee of the celebrated Panacca,
upon which he has built his fortues; and not sat-

have been acquainted with the 0J' oniG1NAL RE

epery case where have administered this medl-
cine, its powerful virtues have not been known


TO fail: this, of itself, and have certificates to
substantaic the fact, would give the lie to MIR.
Swain's bare assertion Perfectly satisfied as |
am, with the increasing orders for it, which are
reaching me from various parts OF the Union, |
should not have thought it necessary to make
this plain statement of the relative merits of the
case, had not Mr.. Swain, on one occasion, when
Lady personally waited on him, to purchase
his Pdnacea and complained Of his extortionate
price, remarking to him that she could purchase


mine for half the money, advised her no, to take
any of it for fear it might produce fatal conse-
qucntcs, and went on to say that it was not gen
uine. Thousands of persons who are now en-
ioying the blessings Of health established by its
use, will bear me out of this assertion, THAr
"PARKER's RENovArINs VEGErABLE PANAcEA"
Is, IN EVERY RESPECT, Equal TO SwArM's, AND
CAN DE TAKEN IN ALL CASES WHERE HIS HAS PRov-
ED EYFIcAcloUs, WITH SECURITY AND FREEDOM.
| AND DO SAY, WITHOUT FEAR OF CONTRADICTION,
| Ann ICAN EsrA BLIsu THE FACT BEYOND THE POSI-
nIL1rY OF DouBT-ruAr My MFncrsE and HIS
ARE ONE hsp THE SAME THING, WITH TIE Egckr-
TIoy OF ANE MrRcuRIAL pREPaRATioN.


JONN A, PARKER.

full articles.headline: fC'oMmunicG,ior.1
full articles.article:
Those WHO have had an opportunity Of
attending .he course of Lectures, now about
10 close, in this Borough, and delivered by
Mr. Joha finch, on the science OF Geology,
&c. have been instructed and Interested
much beyond thcjr previous anticipations'--
In SO concise and SO lucid manner, has be
gone on to unfold to his class, the secrets and
the beauties Of the science; and TO display
to them, feature BY feature, the Internal
structure Of the o,b on which we live, that
he has, in few short weeks, impressed up
on their minds such a general knowledge oi
the subject, as would require months to OBJ
tain, by the common course of study. his
illustrations OF the Classification of fossils;
and his exhibition OF the various specimena,
which he tool, pains to famiiarizc to the
eyes CT his pupils, has likewise given to them
practical idea of Miner alogy, that they
could by no other means acquired Il IS to
be regretted, however, that comparative
few only of our inhabitants, have had the
advantage of these lectures, owing to the fact
that sufficient early publicity was not given
of their commencement, by the proposer.-
Many, thus, were ignorant OF the circum-
stance, who would have otherwise ayaied
themselves Of so favorable an opportunity
to become acquainted, with the too little
known geological arcana of our Globe.


We could wish, on this account, that Mr..
Finch would repeat his course of Lectures
in this Borough. Another Glass; it is pre-
sumed, would be readily formed; and the
youth of both sexes in our town. (the vicini-
tv of which is fertile in Mineral productiens)
would, by storing their minds with knowl-
edge of this interesting science, be capable
Of receiving increased pleasure from their
rides and their rambles through the country

/ was afflicted, several years ago, with rler-

c. MILLS,

Extract Of letter to the Editors of"IHe Sat
urday Erening Post" dated Cooperstown, Otse.
go County, ~ Y. February 9TH, 1897.


Gentlemcn-Observing an advertisement in
your paper, specifying the valuable qualities of
Mr.. Parhers Pnnaceo, il gives me peculiar salts
faction to have an opportunity of proving to the
world the inestimable value which it possesses
1t was my misfortune, while ia Philadelphia.
about two years ago, to be under the necessity
of using mercury, which after eralicating the dis.
case for which used it, brought on more dan
gcrous one, that might have proved f tai, or at
least, left me as it has many others, with brolS
en- constitution, lingering ont a miserable exist
ence, wishing for death to put an end to my mis-
cry. But for the kindness of Mr.. Parker, who
slept forward in a friendly and benevolent man.
ner, peculiar to him, and without fee or reward,
relieved me Of ono of the most loathsome diseas-
es that man ever suffered under, curing me thor
oughlv of the mercuria disease, and restoring
my constitution to former strength and vigor.
Thus, gentlemen, can attest to the value of this
Medicine as a complete renovater and restorative
to the System.

Sir John Copley, who has risen to such

Singleton Copley, II. A.


At late military training in Pike town
ship, Bradford county, Penn. man named
Evetts. aged 73, was killed by Nathaniel
Platt: previously to the murder, Platt had
nearly gouged out both oft old mans eyes.

state Treasury has been all recovered, and

il the theft have been arrested.

and the prospect Of fruit promising.

Fahe Nose.--A French surgeon has late
ly restored to an individual his nose, which
had been frost bitten during the campaign
in Russia. The usual mode was adopted of
turning down a portion of the skin of the
forehead for the purpose. The result is ve-
~ satisfactory. The detormity is scarcely
observable, and the scar in the forehead,
conccaled also in some degree by the hair,
has almost entir ly disappeared. What is
very extraordinary, is, that the person Oh
whom this operation has been performed,
II tcrs 90 lis forehead all the SENSATIONS of
his false nose; The nerves of which arc in fact
furnished by .hc nervous branches intended
for tie forehead.
